oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dirac neutrino mass from a neutrino dark matter model for the galaxy cluster Abell 1689
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Nieuwenhuizen, Theodorus M.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Astrophysics - Cosmology and Nongalactic Astrophysics
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The dark matter in the galaxy cluster Abell 1689 is modelled as an isothermal sphere of neutrinos. New data on the $2d$ mass density allow an accurate description of its core and halo. The model has no "missing baryon problem" and beyond $2.1$ Mpc the baryons have the cosmic mass abundance. Combination of cluster data with the cosmic dark matter fraction -- here supposed to stem from the neutrinos -- leads to a solution of the dark matter riddle by left and right handed neutrinos with mass $(1.861\pm0.016)h_{70}^{-2}\eV/c^2$. The thus far observed absence of neutrinoless double beta decay points to (quasi-) Dirac neutrinos: uncharged electrons with different flavour and mass eigenbasis, as for quarks. Though the cosmic microwave background spectrum is matched up to some 10\% accuracy only, the case is not ruled out because the plasma phase of the early Universe may be turbulent.
Comment: Published version. 12 pages latex, 6 figures
